I am running windows 7 ultimate 64 bit.  I got bex error when trying to run.  I looked further down and the Steamclient.dll caused the problem. I copied the Steamclient.dll, Steam_ap.dll,  and skidrow files from another working skidrow release and overwrote the ones that came with this release.    Game now works.

Played this for about 5 hours and it has been working perfectly. Torrent was great; fast download, easy/fast/simple install (just follow the instructions).

10/10 torrent quality (so far)

The graphics, cut-scenes are quite good. The game play, story and enemies remind me of a mix between Doom/Quake (no reloading of weapons, you can't crouch/crawl, and cyborg enemies) Bioshock (kill enemies by shooting electrical devices or flammable barrels etc; upgrade stations).

If you enjoy such games or movies as I mentioned above you will probably enjoy this. It's a hark back to classic FPS games before anything cutting edge or innovative like gravity/portal guns rose to prominence. 

It gets a little repetitive at times, and is also quite challenging, even for a seasoned FPS player. Overall I give Hard Reset a solid 7 out of 10. It's well worth playing while you are waiting for the next big game to come out (still waiting for Half Life 2: Episode 3 to come out!!!).

@ mahyaz96 yes, that is my idea. How else are game developers going to work with file sharing? It's a loosing battle. Instead they should provide a secure, working version of the game to download instantly online and then offer a direct, easy to use donate service within the game menu and at the end. if you thought the game was good and enjoyed it you can donate a nominal amount, say $5 or $10 which goes directly to the company responsible for creating the game. They could also integrate optional upgrades, extensions or packages which you can buy if you want them - but they are not critical to the main game storyline.

Also, another idea is crowdsourcing t produce games. You design a game, market it, get  a few thousand people to all chip in a few bucks, make the game and then everyone who contributed will get various rewards such as mechanise, direct downloads to the game, extra add-ons or packages etc.

There's lots of ways to make money, the sooner companies realise that the old way of creating, packaging and selling games in retail format is dead the better.. rather than making common folk who P2P out to be criminals!

I know that I downloaded Portal 2 I was extremely satisfied with the game.. but what should I do then? Should I go out and buy the game just because I liked it? No, I won't do that and neither will most other people. However, if they had a donate feature where I could donate using Paypal or something like that I would have been more than happy to send them a $5-10 directly. Better than nothing.
